Award.AbstractNarration:
This travel grant provides partial support for U.S. participation in the "Young Topologists Meeting 2018", held in Copenhagen, Denmark by Copenhagen University, July 9th-13th, 2018. The "Young Topologists Meeting" (YTM) is an annual European conference focused on the work of graduate students and early career researchers in topology, that brings in participants from all over the world. At the YTM, junior topologists present their work to a large international audience, and also attend mini-courses taught by senior topologists. The conference provides opportunities for the participants to meet new colleagues and mentors, and to form research collaborations. Its open and supportive atmosphere encourages early career mathematicians, including those from underrepresented groups, to pursue research careers in topology.

The YTM is an annual event, first started in 2007, which traditionally alternates between Copenhagen, Denmark and Lausanne, Switzerland (except in 2017 when it was held in Stockholm). The conference features parallel sessions of contributed talks by graduate students and early career researchers, covering a broad spectrum of topics in topology. In addition to these talks, there will be mini-courses by two senior topologists, discussing the connections between algebraic topology and other fields, and focusing on open problems and new directions. This year Michael Hill (UCLA, US) will give a course on equivariant stable homotopy theory and Kathryn Mann (Brown University, US) will give a course on foliated fiber bundles and their applications. The conference web page is available at http://www.math.ku.dk/english/research/conferences/2018/ytm2018.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded mathematics PhD students and postdoctoral researchers working at US institutions to travel to Copenhagen and attend the Young Topologists Meeting at the University of Copenhagen. Travel was partially or completely funded for 51 participants from US institutions, many of whom presented their research in half-hour talks to their peers and colleagues. Attendance at the YTM allowed young mathematicians from many US institutions to begin collaborations, form working relationships with their European peers, and learn about cutting edge research in their field.

The primary intellectual merit of this grant was in making it possible for young American researchers in topology and geometry to (i) attend two mini-courses given by leading figures in their fields (Kathryn Mann of Brown University and Mike Hill of UCLA), (ii) begin forming working relationships and collaborations with peers and mentors overseas with whom they might otherwise not come into contact and (iii)  present their own research to an international audience and attend lectures given by their peers on new work.

In determining criteria for funding applicants, special attention was paid to applicants from institutions that are not well represented at such gatherings and whether or not they were members of underrepresented minorities in mathematics. The PI attempted to make sure that such applicants, where suitable, were funded. This is line with a broader goal of increasing participation in high level mathematics research by underrepresented groups.
